turn.0: ELI5: In Chemistry, why are they called the Noble Gases? I know they "don't share", but is that a crack at aristocrats or more of a Buddhist-style respectful reference to the nobility?
turn.1: They need an enormous amount of power and expertise though, you cant just flip a Switch and have them run, and you certainly can’t by yourself.
turn.2: Good thing Switzerland has a shitload of nuclear power   (Bavaria and several other regions in that area might have similar capabilities, and even if not they could just go to Switzerland)
turn.3: Ya but not autonomous nuclear power. Maybe you are a nuclear physicist and nuclear engineer but you still can’t be in both places at once and do the maintenance
turn.4: Hmm, we were mainly just talking about regions trying to survive some sort of apocalypse   Yeah the Alps in general seem like a good place for that, (google alpine redoubt or national redoubt, even Mussolini had a pretty good one), and that being said the entirety of the Western World for the most part could be used. Even Svalbard north of Norway is famously thought of as a place to preserve things
turn.5: Not living things. Its cold and hard to grow crops. They are good at preserving things specifically because living things don't survive there well
turn.6: Okay well crispr and all the indoor agriculture techniques post-WWII solve all those problems   I mean they're figuring out ways to grow plants in spaceships and terraform Mars I'm sure they can do it underground in Earth
turn.7: If you have enough infrastructure to do so on a useful scale then you aren't in an apocalypse.
turn.8: What if the rest of the world on the surface,  not in bunkers, all die in a nuclear war but the Swiss (among others) are safe underground with a fully functioning society   Is that considered an apocalypse?
turn.9: most would call it science fiction, or total fantasy. If society is functioning then you don't need to make gold.
